awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Integrating Fracture Nucleation and Propagation into Optimization: Towards Materials with Optimal Fracture Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
To date, the vast majority of topology optimization advancements have restricted attention to problems where the underlying materials are assumed to deform elastically without ever fracturing. However, it is well established that even a simple variation in microstructure can have a profound influence on the effective fracture properties of materials. Hence, optimization of microstructural topology has the potential to revolutionize the discovery of materials with unprecedented fracture properties. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award supports fundamental research to put forth a theoretical and computational framework that identifies linear elastic brittle materials whose microstructures have optimized fracture nucleation and propagation behaviors. This research will explore the topological space to create microstructures in linear elastic brittle materials that lead to improved fracture behaviors and enhanced energy dissipation. The insights generated will contribute to the progress of science by paving the way required to formulate a theory that systematically discovers novel geometries and mechanisms toward enhanced toughness. This research will allow advancement in other fields, such as civil and aerospace structures and medical implants, ultimately contributing towards a broad range of applications for national health and prosperity. The project will also enrich the multidisciplinary course curriculum and provide opportunities to educate and train graduate students in theoretical optimization, advanced modeling, and experimental techniques. 

The objective of the research is to create a transformative and mathematically rigorous approach to optimize microstructures with maximized fracture properties. A formulation of topology optimization that integrates fracture nucleation and propagation into the mechanical response of materials, which can both deform elastically and fracture, will be derived and implemented numerically. A specific subset of materials, linear elastic brittle materials with two phases, will be addressed in this project. The derived formulation will be employed to identify optimal microstructural topologies in linear elastic brittle porous composite materials with improved fracture properties. These optimized topologies will be fabricated and systematically validated by experiments. This work will generate new insights about the optimal geometries and dominating mechanisms that enhance fracture performance. The project will also build the foundation of a new ability to manipulate cracks and opens up possibilities for a wide range of applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Board of Trustees of the University of Illinois

por.por_cntn:
In this EAGER project, we have created innovative topology optimization frameworks (e.g., see Figs. 1–5) for optimizing the design of structures to significantly enhance their stiffness, strength, and toughness. As an educational effort, we also developed a modular 2D and 3D topology optimization educational software, FEniTop, to facilitate the implementation of the various topology optimization frameworks with excellent efficiency. Our created frameworks involve the distribution of materials and fiber directions in composites. Throughout the design process, we explored various failure criteria,domain geometries, and considerations for 3D printing-induced anisotropy, ultimately yielding designs with robust load capacities in diverse scenarios. After constructing a library of optimized designs, we harnessed 3D printing techniques to fabricate them and conducted experiments to confirm their superior mechanical performance. These designs demonstrated remarkable elasticity, deforming elastically until meeting the predefined failure criteria. This demonstration not only validated our proposed topology optimization frameworks but also revealed several mechanisms for enhancing structural fracture performance, paving the way for the automatic discovery of superior structures for engineering applications.

Our research activities in this EAGER project have culminated in the publication of impactful papers and engaging conference reports, including 8 journal papers, 2 conference presentations, and 2 poster presentations. The theoretical and computational frameworks, along with the fabrication approaches developed in the EAGER project, are ready to extend and contribute to advancements in various disciplines such as civil engineering, mechanical engineering, aerospace engineering, and architected materials. Moreover, the outcomes of this project have been woven into a newly created course, Structural Design Optimization, by the Principal Investigator (PI). This course, along with associated educational materials, has been designed to disseminate state-of-the-art results to senior undergraduate and graduate students across diverse departments. The goal is to equip students with proficiency in structural optimization, ensuring they are well-prepared for the challenges of the ever-evolving engineering landscape. Through these initiatives, we aim to bridge the gap between research and education, fostering a broader understanding of structural design optimization especially for improving fracture performance.


Last Modified: 02/26/2024
Modified by: Xiaojia S Zhang

por.por_txt_cntn:
In this EAGER project, we have created innovative topology optimization frameworks (e.g., see Figs. 15) for optimizing the design of structures to significantly enhance their stiffness, strength, and toughness. As an educational effort, we also developed a modular 2D and 3D topology optimization educational software, FEniTop, to facilitate the implementation of the various topology optimization frameworks with excellent efficiency. Our created frameworks involve the distribution of materials and fiber directions in composites. Throughout the design process, we explored various failure criteria,domain geometries, and considerations for 3D printing-induced anisotropy, ultimately yielding designs with robust load capacities in diverse scenarios. After constructing a library of optimized designs, we harnessed 3D printing techniques to fabricate them and conducted experiments to confirm their superior mechanical performance. These designs demonstrated remarkable elasticity, deforming elastically until meeting the predefined failure criteria. This demonstration not only validated our proposed topology optimization frameworks but also revealed several mechanisms for enhancing structural fracture performance, paving the way for the automatic discovery of superior structures for engineering applications.


Our research activities in this EAGER project have culminated in the publication of impactful papers and engaging conference reports, including 8 journal papers, 2 conference presentations, and 2 poster presentations. The theoretical and computational frameworks, along with the fabrication approaches developed in the EAGER project, are ready to extend and contribute to advancements in various disciplines such as civil engineering, mechanical engineering, aerospace engineering, and architected materials. Moreover, the outcomes of this project have been woven into a newly created course, Structural Design Optimization, by the Principal Investigator (PI). This course, along with associated educational materials, has been designed to disseminate state-of-the-art results to senior undergraduate and graduate students across diverse departments. The goal is to equip students with proficiency in structural optimization, ensuring they are well-prepared for the challenges of the ever-evolving engineering landscape. Through these initiatives, we aim to bridge the gap between research and education, fostering a broader understanding of structural design optimization especially for improving fracture performance.
